learning_outcomes.description: Have an advanced understanding of the importance of theoretical thinking and design in IR research
Be able to identify and interrogate both tacit and explicit theoretical commitments in IR research schemes
Creatively and successfully build and defend theoretical frameworks for your own research endeavours
Understand and negotiate the 'theory-dependence' of all knowledge critically, an be able to communicate the implications of this both to general audiences and in academic settings
Have an advanced understanding of the relationship between theories and practices, and be able to successfully unpack and interrogate this

assessments.due_date: The quiz will be held each week from Weeks 2 to 12 in the scheduled seminar time. 3/03/2026 - 19/05/2026
assessments.task_description:
There will be eleven written quizzes held in the seminar beginning in Week 2 and concluding in Week 12. The class will be provided with a list of approximately 70 terms that are crucial to understanding the course, organized by week, prior to the start of semester.

Each week I will select 2 terms that were covered during the previous week's seminar. During the seminar you will be given 13 minutes to write a definition of one of the two terms I have selected from this list and displayed on the screen. Please note that the time the quiz is offered will vary from week to week, but that it will occur at some stage during the scheduled seminar time depending on that week's structure. 

The definition has two parts: Part A asks you to identify the basic meaning of a term. Part B requires you to explain why this term matters to international relations. Part A is worth 1 mark, part B is worth 3 marks (4 marks total). 

There are 11 (eleven) opportunities to take the quiz, but you only need to do it 7 (seven) times, forming 28% of your grade. If you do more than 7 quizzes, we will select your top 7 results. This means that you can miss up to four quizzes without a penalty. Please note that there are NO opportunities to re-take individual quizzes and no alternative assessment available except in the very specific circumstances outlined below. In other words: be organized and try to take as many quizzes as early as you can! If you do more than 7 quizzes, you can seriously improve your grade as we will take your top results.

Each week I will run through the definition from the previous week and provide examples of what constituted excellent work. As these terms are crucial components of international relations theory and the study of international relations, I will be able to use your knowledge to enhance class discussion and overall learning in the course. The final exam for the course has a definitions component, so by doing this activity weekly and discussing the definitions during each lecture you will also enhance your performance on the final exam. 

Alternative Assessment

If you have a Disability Action Plan that applies to the quiz please contact me ASAP. We can make accommodations in the seminar for many of the issues documented in Disability Action Plans (e.g., if you cannot handwrite exams).

The quizzes are scheduled to take 13 minutes in order to provide extra time for any student who requires that extra time in a Disability Action Plan. If your Disability Action Plan requires you to have additional extra time please get in touch as soon as possible to discuss alternatives.

If a student has a genuine (documented) reason they have been unable to attend the seminar on 7 occasions, a make up test will be offered late in the semester, using the same master list of definitions. Given the extensive flexibility built into this assessment and the fact you can miss 4 quizzes with no penalty it is very unlikely that alternative assessment will be granted except in truly exceptional and documented circumstances, e.g. serious illness, sudden change of job, etc. The make-up quiz is NOT designed for students who miss one or two classes due to minor illness or do not plan ahead and miss too many quizzes early in the semester.

Please note that the make-up quiz only comes in one form: you do all 7 definitions from a list I provide before the start of the make-up quiz in 95 minutes. This is the only format for the make-up quiz (although extra time can be provided for those with Disability Action Plans).

To be eligible for alternative assessment, you must contact me by 30 MARCH with your documentation. If there is an unforeseeable change to your circumstances (eg illness, new job) after that date, please contact me as soon as you can with documentation.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.assessment_title: Theory and Crisis Essay Source Analysis and Check In
assessments.task_description:
This assessment requires you to prepare a source assessment for your Crisis Essay. This source assessment should be no more than 1600 words (excluding the lists of titles in parts 1 and 2 below). Requirements:

  • Provide a one sentence thesis statement of the argument you will be making in your essay (2 marks)
  • Identify the quality of 8 sources you will use in the essay. Explicit instructions will be provided on how to do this, but it will consist of 3 parts:
  1. Identify 6 sources for your essay using ONLY the UQ library search engine and provide this list.
  2. Identify 6 sources for your essay using a generative AI platform and provide this list.
  3. From this list of twelve choose the best 8 for your essay. You must indicate a) why you chose the 8 you chose from the list of 12 b) how you can tell they are good quality sources c) why they will be specifically good for your essay. (5 marks)
  4. You must provide a 1 paragraph reflection on the differences, strengths and weaknesses of the list of sources generated through the library and through AI (5 marks).

EXAMPLES AND MARKING CRITERIA WILL BE PROVIDED IN CLASS AND ON BLACKBOARD

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Assignments for this course will be submitted electronically via Blackboard and using Turnitin.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Each student will be required to write an essay of 3000 words in length. This essay will ask you to explain a crisis or incident in international politics and compare two theories, making an argument about which theoretical perspective best illuminates the chosen crisis and the strengths and weaknesses of both. A list of crises will be provided to you on Blackboard along with extensive guidance on how to complete this assignment.

Assignments should be fully referenced and include a reference list. The reference list is not included in the word count. Students are expected to use either Chicago 18th Notes and Bibliography or Chicago Author-Date (18th). In-text citations will count towards the word limit; footnote references will not.

All assignments submitted are to be the original and individual work of the student submitting them. The assignment must be submitted electronically through Turnitin in Word.doc format (not PDF). 

Penalties will apply for late submission (10% per day) and excessive variation from the word limit. More than 10% variation from the word limit will result in a 10% penalty. 

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Assignments for this course will be submitted electronically via Blackboard and using Turnitin.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
This is a final exam covering the content of the entire course. It is composed of two parts.

Part A uses the same list of definitions provided for the weekly quiz. Five of these definitions will be selected to be answered in short answer form. Extensive explanation will be provided in lectures on Blackboard regarding format. Each definition has two components: the first should define the term/concept/idea/event, and the second explain why it is important for international relations. The first component is worth 1 point and the second component worth 2 points. The first part of the exam will be worth 15% of the total exam grade. 

Part B is an essay question. There will be a choice of essay questions, from which students will select one question to answer. The essays will require students to compare at least two theories of international relations we have discussed in the course. Marking criteria for the essay will be provided on Blackboard and the essay will be worth 17% of the exam grade.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.topic:
What is Theory, and what is it for?

(Seminar 1)This seminar asks the question: what is theory in international relations, and why do we use it? Working from examples, we explore some of the challenges faced by any attempt at social and political inquiry, and consider and discuss the implications this has for developing compelling analyses of social and political problems.



Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_title: What is Theory, and what is it for?
learning_activities.topic_description: What is Theory, and what is it for? (Seminar 1)This seminar asks the question: what is theory in international relations, and why do we use it?  Working from examples, we explore some of the challenges faced by any attempt at social and political inquiry, and consider and discuss the implications this has for developing compelling analyses of social and political problems.

learning_activities.topic:
Classical Realism and Classical Liberalism

in Seminar 2, we begin by examining classical theories of international relations, liberalism and realism, and consider their impact on how people understood the international world. These theories have their origins deep in the past of thinking about international politics.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Classical Realism and Classical Liberalism in Seminar 2, we begin by examining classical theories of international relations, liberalism and realism, and consider their impact on how people understood the international world. These theories have their origins deep in the past of thinking about international politics.

learning_activities.topic:
Neorealism or structural realism

In this seminar we will discuss neorealist approaches to international politics and their impact. We consider what the main contribution of neorealism is, and its ability to understand, predict and explain war and conflict.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Neorealism or structural realism In this seminar we will discuss neorealist approaches to international politics and their impact. We consider what the main contribution of neorealism is, and its ability to understand, predict and explain war and conflict.

learning_activities.topic:
Neoliberal Institutionalism and Global Governance

In this seminar we will consider neoliberal approaches to international politics, their strengths and limitations. We consider how liberal and neoliberal approaches led to the creation of the liberal international order, and how neoliberals deal with the problem of cooperation. We consider how these theoretical ideas are being confirmed and disconfirmed by contemporary politics.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Neoliberal Institutionalism and Global Governance In this seminar we will consider neoliberal approaches to international politics, their strengths and limitations. We consider how liberal and neoliberal approaches led to the creation of the liberal international order, and how neoliberals deal with the problem of cooperation. We consider how these theoretical ideas are being confirmed and disconfirmed by contemporary politics.

learning_activities.topic:
Constructivism

This seminar examines English School approaches to IR theory. We probe another way of understanding how states engage with each other and form 'orders' in international politics, and how these orders can erode and re-form.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Constructivism This seminar examines English School approaches to IR theory. We probe another way of understanding how states engage with each other and form 'orders' in international politics, and how these orders can erode and re-form.

learning_activities.topic:
The English School

This seminar examines English School Approaches to world politics.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05

learning_activities.topic:
Feminism and Critical Theory

Seminar 7 on Feminism and Critical Theory examines these approaches to international relations.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05

learning_activities.topic:
Race, Empire, Post-colonialism

This seminar considers the impact of race, empire and post-colonialism on IR theory.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05

learning_activities.topic:
International Law and International Relations

This seminar considers how we theorize about the existence and operation of international law in world politics.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: International Law and International Relations This seminar considers how we theorize about the existence and operation of international law in world politics.

learning_activities.topic:
Order and Justice in World Politics

This seminar examines the relationship between order and justice in international politics.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Order and Justice in World Politics This seminar examines the relationship between order and justice in international politics.

learning_activities.topic:
International History and International Relations Theory

This class considers how we theorize and explain the operation (or otherwise) of international law in world politics.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: International History and International Relations Theory This class considers how we theorize and explain the operation (or otherwise) of international law in world politics.

learning_activities.topic:
Cutting Edge Theory and World Politics

In this class we will take a look at the key debates in today's world and see what the leading international relations journals have to say about them. How good is theory at explaining contemporary politics and how responsive can theory be to fast-moving world affairs?

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05

How good is theory at explaining contemporary politics and how responsive can theory be to fast-moving world affairs?
